conclusion: Only the horizontal rod MN moves; rails AB, CD, and connection BDE are fixed.
The only element in which a motional emf is produced is MN.
For a straight conductor of length l moving with velocity v perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field B, the motional emf is ε = B l v.
The direction of B is into the page, v is downward, l is horizontal, so v, B, and l are mutually perpendicular.
The rails and the piece BDE have negligible resistance.
The rod MN has resistance per unit length r, so for length l its resistance is R = r l.
Using Ohm’s law, the current in the circuit is I = ε / R = B l v / (r l) = B v / r.
Current I flowing through a conductor of length l in a magnetic field B experiences a force F = I l B.
The magnetic force on the rod is F = B² l v / r.
Using the right-hand rule, the magnetic force is upward and acts as a braking force.
The rod starts from rest, accelerates, and reaches a speed at which the magnetic braking force equals its weight.
At terminal speed vₜ, magnetic force equals gravitational force: B² l vₜ / r = m g.
Solve for the terminal speed: vₜ = (m g r) / (B² l).
The constant (terminal) speed attained by the conductor rod MN is v = m g r / (B² l).
